explanation: Putha, replying to such an email is dangerous. It’s like giving your school ID to a stranger without checking who they are.
Malli, answering this kind of email is unsafe. Think of it like sharing exam papers with someone you don’t know — you can’t trust it.
Putha, replying to unknown emails is like installing an app without checking permissions — it puts your data at risk.
Malli, responding directly is risky. Just like signing a blank paper, you don’t know how it will be misused.
Putha, replying confirms your email is active. Hackers then target you more, just like thieves mark houses that open the door.
Malli, this reply will validate your address to scammers. It’s like showing your national ID copy to a random person on the road.
Putha, replying gives attackers a confirmation channel. In IT terms, it’s like sending a live ping that tells them you are online.
Malli, responding opens communication with threat actors. It’s similar to establishing an insecure connection without encryption.
Duwa, replying is unsafe. It’s like giving your class timetable to a stranger — they don’t need to know and it puts you at risk.
Akka, replying confirms your identity to someone suspicious. Like answering a random phone call and sharing family details.

Akka, sending a reply gives away your active email. It’s like broadcasting your phone number to unknown groups — unsafe.

Akka, replying creates risk. It’s like giving strangers your attendance sheet — they now know where to find you.
Duwa, this reply acts like a handshake with a hacker. In IT, it’s basically a handshake protocol — but unsecured.
Akka, replying is the worst step. It establishes direct contact with attackers, just like opening a locked door for a stranger.
Putha, clicking unknown links is risky. Just imagine opening a stranger’s parcel without knowing who sent it. It can carry hidden traps. Always check the bank’s official website instead.

Malli, clicking on links in emails can install harmful software or steal your details. It’s like letting a stranger borrow your school bag without checking what’s inside. Safer to access the bank directly.

Putha, phishing links look real but are traps. Think of it like a fake tuition notice on the wall with wrong exam dates. If you trust it blindly, you may get into trouble. Open the official site instead.
Malli, clicking such links exposes your credentials. It’s like giving your ATM card to a stranger claiming to help — dangerous. Always use the official bank portal.
Putha, attackers design fake pages to trick you. It’s like copying notes from a wrong textbook — looks correct but misleads you. Always open the bank’s official website directly.
